It is great to see that environmental education and awareness is growing among schools at various levels. When I was in high school I was fortunate enough to have an environmental science teacher that was actively involved with making our high school a more energy efficient and eco-friendly place, implementing a program incorporating produce from local farms, creating an organic school garden, and aiding a district-wide plan to cut back on energy use. This individual's leadership, friendly demeanor, and understanding of environmental issues and concerns is what influenced me to pursue an environmental studies education at the university level.

Flash-forward four years later and I find myself in an environmental studies capstone class that is centered around Climate Change. The class is very interdisciplinary, relying on experts from a variety of backgrounds and fields of study to provide guest lectures and answer questions. Some common themes are evident, particularly the need for citizens that are educated on the topic and are able to effectively communicate the different facets of Climate Change to their peers. This article provides a refreshing bit of news, proving that environmental education can play a larger role in both the curriculum, infrastructure, and operations in our schools.

The potential for wind and solar as key energy sources in the United States is an issue that I hope will receive more attention. When the energy system is viewed in the context of Climate Change and the emission of greenhouse gases, it seems evident that there is a dire need for emissions reductions across the board.

I am currently involved in an interactive capstone environmental studies class that is centered around the topic of Climate Change. It relies on a multitude of guest lecturers from a wide range of fields and backgrounds. One common theme among these experts is the need to shift people's consciousness towards achieving emissions reductions and implementing sustainable practices and technologies. No easy task by any means, and the way in which to go about it is hotly debated. The science is there, and it is credible, saying that human beings are contributing to, and escalating, the greenhouse effect. Effects such as increased occurrence of extreme weather events, changes in precipitation patterns, rising sea levels, and the loss of biodiversity are all on the horizon (and some are already in evidence) and necessitate a lifestyle change.Encouraging the use of solar and wind technologies is just one of many different options that warrants further pursuit.

Asteriod doesn't understand that when the main author of the article admits that the recent temperature uptick relative to the  fossil record is not robust, that author is stating that the position and magnitude of modern temperature increases relative to the fossil record is not statistically significant. Given the hype the media gave to this study, this admission amounts to some degree a retraction of the significance of this article.

The Times Headline of March 7 reads: "Global Temperatures Highest in 4,000 Years" based on the Marcott study in "Science" ... The report was immediately cut to shreds in the skeptic blogosphere, led by Steve McIntyre but includes other commentators as well.

Now one of the Marcott authors has retracted the alarmist spin which "Science" magazine and his coauthors played in the press. No doubt, this climb down comes in response to the McIntyre expose.

My first question is why this scandal is being buried in a blog? Why isn't it being reported by the Times in a retraction story given the same positioning as the original claims?

Also we may ask where is the professoriat in all this? McIntyre is a mining executive who happens to have expertise in analyzing large data sets. Where were the science reporters who dutifully transcribed press releases? What about the spinners and peer-reviewers at "Science"? Were they all party to this misconduct?

Ultimately, the real scandal here is not the Marcott paper alone. This is just one of several highly dubious papers coming out of the climatology profession, led, of course by Michael Mann's thoroughly repudiated "Hockey Stick" theory of catastrophic global climate warming caused by the rise of a few hundred parts per million of CO2.

No wonder the public has tuned out global warming alarmism, followed by politicians who don't want to be caught on the wrong side of so-called "settled science".

Professor Reinhardt -- As you know, most health insurance policies are paid for with pre-tax dollars, whereas out-of-pocket expenses are paid for with after-tax dollars. (Something I think needs to change.) So, by recommending that someone drop their insurance, you are recommending that they give up a large tax benefit.

Also, let's say that the employer makes a contribution to an employee's premium -- they are unlikely to add that amount back to the employee's paycheck if the policy is foregone, so it would be money left on the table.

In terms of protection against unlikely, expensive events, if affordable catastrophe insurance is available, it could be a viable alternative to full coverage.
